title: How to Have an Oktoberfest Party

steps.headline: Host an outdoor party.
steps.description: Oktoberfest parties are traditionally held outside, so host an outdoor bash if possible. Set up long picnic tables, and if you can afford it, rent tents to mimic those set up by breweries at Munich Oktoberfests. In addition to lending authenticity, beer tents will also help you handle rainy weather.

steps.headline: Use blue and white decorations.
steps.description: Cobalt blue and white are the traditional Bavarian colors. Get your hands on German and Bavarian flags and hang them throughout your backyard. Look online or at your local party supplies store for blue and white streamers, napkins, plates, and plastic silverware. Evergreen wreaths and stein centerpieces will also help create a genuine Bavarian feel.

steps.headline: Play festive, traditional music.
steps.description: If you want to splurge on a local band that plays traditional German music, make sure to book them early, as their schedule will likely fill up during the season. You can also connect your mobile device to speakers and search for Oktoberfest playlists on your preferred streaming service. You can find useful lists of German and English songs that are typically played at Oktoberfests online.

steps.headline: Wear lederhosen and dirndls.
steps.description: Go all out and wear traditional garb, and encourage your guests to do the same. Purchasing authentic lederhosen for men and dirndls for women can get expensive, but you can save by buying a costume online or perusing your local costume shop. If all else fails, try looking online for inexpensive shirts with German or Bavarian flags, or just encourage guests to wear blue and white.

steps.headline: Serve Oktoberfest-style domestic beer to keep your budget in check.
steps.description: Starting in August in most locations, you can find domestic (U.S.) Oktoberfest-style beer at grocery and liquor stores. You could also support your local businesses and see if any nearby breweries have Oktoberfest-styles available. To calculate how much beer you should get, plan on each guest having two beers per hour.

steps.headline: Import beer from Munich if you want to stay authentic.
steps.description: If you live near a quality beer shop, you might be able to find a good selection of imported Oktoberfest beers. If your budget isn’t a concern, you could have beer shipped from one of the six Munich-based breweries. The six Munich breweries are Augustiner, Hacker-Pschorr, Hofbräu, Löwenbräu, Paulaner, and Spaten. Only Hacker-Pschorr, Hofbräu, Paulaner, and Spaten ship to the United States. Traditionally, Spaten should be the first keg tapped or bottle opened. When the keg is tapped or bottles are cracked, the host should say, “O’zapft is!” (It is tapped!)

steps.headline: Have a beer swap.
steps.description: Cut your budget by encouraging your guests to bring their own Oktoberfest-style beer. In addition to decreasing your costs, having a beer swap will allow everyone to get a taste of a variety of brews. Mention in your invitations that there will be a beer swap, and ask your guests to bring a six pack of their favorite Oktoberfest-style beer for swapping.

steps.headline: Twist up some homemade soft pretzels.
steps.description: While it’s a lengthy process, making your own pretzels from scratch will impress your guests and lend authenticity to your party. Mix water, sugar, salt, yeast, flour, and butter together to make the dough. Form your pretzels, dip them in boiling water and baking soda, brush them with an egg wash and sprinkle them with pretzel salt, then bake them for 12 to 14 minutes. If you don’t have time, you can just purchase ready-made soft pretzels.

steps.headline: Make a Bavarian honey mustard for your pretzels.
steps.description: Whip up a traditional dipping sauce by mixing 5 ounces (about 150 mL) of creme fraiche, 3 tablespoons of honey, and 2 tablespoons of mustard. Combine them well, then add salt and sugar to taste. If you need to make a larger supply, just stick to the ratios and double or triple each ingredient.

steps.headline: Offer a slew of sausages.
steps.description: An assortment of sausages will make awesome appetizers for your party. Try cooking beer basted bratwurst by grilling sausages for about 8 minutes, or just before they’re done. Melt the butter in a pot over medium heat, then add the sausages and beer. Simmer the sausages over very low heat for 20 minutes to an hour. The longer you simmer them, the stronger their beer flavor will be. Cut your brats up and serve them with toothpicks so guests can easily serve themselves. Put them out with a dish of sauerkraut and onions caramelized with brown sugar.

steps.headline: Roast a chicken for the main course.
steps.description: Brathendl, or roasted chicken, is one of the most popular Oktoberfest foods. Wash the chicken inside and out, then pat it dry with a towel. Mix the spices and herbs together, rub the chicken inside and out with the mixture, then place it in a roasting pan covered with a half inch (about a centimeter) of water. Cut the butter into small pieces and place them on top of the chicken. Roast it in an oven preheated to 325 degrees Fahrenheit (about 165 degrees Celsius) for an hour. Baste it with the pan juices every 15 to 20 minutes. Serve it with boiled potatoes, radish, sauerkraut, or red cabbage.

steps.headline: Keep checklists and set a budget.
steps.description: Make checklists of all the recipe items, beer, decorations, and other supplies you’ll need. Set a budget, and add up the costs of these items before actually purchasing them. Throwing a theme party, especially one that’s centered on alcohol, can get expensive. Give yourself a month or two to plan your party and purchase your supplies.

steps.headline: Invite your guests at least a month in advance.
steps.description: Send out social media or printed invitations well in advance of your party, and include RSVP instructions. Ask your guests to RSVP one to two weeks before your party’s date. Sending invitations that ask your guests to RSVP will help you accurately estimate your head count. Be sure to mention attire, details about a beer swap, or any other information your guests might need.

steps.headline: Recruit helpers for setup, clean-up, and to keep an eye on things.
steps.description: Ask your family or closest friends for help, and assign them specific duties. Have a couple of people help you put up decorations, food and drink, and complete other setup duties. Enlist your inner circle to help you clean up so you don’t have to handle a backyard disaster on your own. Having a few people you trust keep an eye on things will also come in handy. Ask them to make sure people are having a good time, behaving themselves, and to handle or report any issues to you.

steps.headline: Use ice filled trash cans to chill your beer.
steps.description: You don't have to splurge on a large cooler for your bottles or keg if you don't already have one. Keep your brews cold by storing bottles or kegs in clean trash cans filled with ice. Purchase a new inexpensive trash can, or wash a gently used one out thoroughly.

steps.headline: Prepare for tipsy guests.
steps.description: Since beer is a central part of an Oktoberfest party, you should prepare for overindulgent guests and their antics. Store breakables and valuables in an off-limits room. Encourage your guests to designate sober drivers or to take public transportation or Uber. If necessary, pull a rowdy guest aside, offer water, and politely reference that they should stop drinking. You could delicately handle a rowdy guest by saying, “I don’t know about you, but I sure can’t drink like I used to! I think it’s time to switch to water for a while.”
